content:

Two were killed by poachers, while the other 19 died from natural causes like getting stuck in swamps, fighting, aging, or tiger attacks.

As the rhino population grows, so does the number dying from habitat issues.

The park is working to manage wetlands and grasslands to help protect rhinos.

Currently, there are 694 rhinos in the park.
summary: In the past 10 months, 21 rhinos died in Chitwan National Park; only 2 due to poaching, with the others dying of natural causes such as in-fighting, ageing, tiger attacks, and habitat issues.

title:
**Statement on Israel-Iran Conflict**

The Humanist World Protection League (HWPL) expresses deep concern over the escalating conflict between Israel and Iran.

**Call for De-escalation**

HWPL urges both nations to immediately cease all hostilities and return to diplomatic negotiations. The conflict threatens the safety of civilians and risks further regional instability.

**Rejection of Violence**

HWPL condemns the use of violence and calls for peaceful resolution through dialogue and empathy. All parties should respect international law and human rights.

**Long-Term Solution**

HWPL stresses the importance of a comprehensive and just solution that addresses the root causes of the conflict. This includes recognition of each other's rights and the promotion of coexistence.
content:
Iran and Israel are fighting, causing concerns worldwide. The conflict has claimed lives, including civilians.

International law has been broken by attacking facilities in other countries.

Innocent civilians suffer most from war.

HWPL calls for an end to violence and peace talks between Iran and Israel.

The international community should help build peace and provide aid.

A peace agreement would benefit future generations.

HWPL is committed to ending wars and promoting peace.
summary:
The recent violent conflict between Iran and Israel is causing significant concerns in the international community. The two nations that do not share borders are mobilizing high-end weaponry to attack each other and kill human lives.1 April 2024, the Israeli military attacked the Iranian consulate in Syria. A strike against a non-military facility in a third nation, a nation not directly involved in the conflict, infringes international law and constitutes a war crime. Moreover, on 13 April, Iran responded by attacking Israel’s land. Both nations have pointed their guns directly at each other, and there are growing concerns in the international community that the attacks could escalate into another war.
The Israel-Hamas War in Gaza has killed 30,000 since last year, and news outlets reported on dire situations in Gaza, running out of space for proper burial. The war that has persisted in the region over the past century continuously overshadows the prospect of the coexistence of the human race.
It is a clear indication that the greatest victims of war are innocent civilians. How could those lost lives ever be brought back? What could compensate for the outcry of children and the anguish of the youth in devastated dwellings?
HWPL strongly supports the voices of the citizens, the true protagonists of the global village, who oppose war and call for peace. All nations of the global community must uphold the citizens’ demands, thereby ceasing the unjust war and joining to accomplish peace. Organizations worldwide, in alliance with HWPL as peace solidarity, urge Iran and Israel to put a stop to the acts of aggression immediately and to come forward for conversations to usher in peace.
HWPL recommend that the international community take necessary measures to facilitate the formation of amicable relations between the two nations and provide humanitarian aid. It would be reasonable for all countries to support an international legal instrument for peace that embodies the long-yearned path to peace and to comply with its contents so that we leave a legacy of peace for future generations. HWPL will not spare its efforts for peace and cessation of wars.

title: Swiss government giving $9.01 million for tourism projects.
content:
Switzerland will provide 9 million Swiss francs to Nepal for a four-year trekking tourism project.

The project aims to benefit around 100,000 people in 29 local areas of Koshi Province.

It will support local culture, art, production, job creation, and sustainable tourism development.

The Swiss Ambassador hopes the project will boost the economy and environment in the area.

The project is expected to increase tourism and income sources for locals through eco-tourism.
summary: Swiss government funds 9.01 million Swiss francs for a four-year trekking-based tourism project in Nepal, benefiting 29 local levels and 100,000 locals, supporting local economy and promoting sustainable tourism.

title: Four people were arrested for leaking Grade 12 exam papers.
content: Four people were arrested in Kathmandu for writing answers on leaked Grade-12 exam papers. The arrested individuals are Madhav Tripathi, Sabin Paudel, Sitesh Kumar Yadav, and Roshan Ranabhat. The arrest was made during the exam, and an investigation is underway according to the Education Act.
summary: Kathmandu police arrested four individuals with Grade-12 answer sheets following an exam paper leak, investigating under the Education Act, 2028.

title: arrest-warrant-issued-against-20-people-including-former-officials-of-bal-mandir
content: Arrest warrants have been issued for 20 people, including former Bal Mandir officials, for illegally using the charity's land for business. The complaint was filed at the CIB on Thursday, and the investigation found that the land was leased out at a low cost, causing loss to the charity.
summary: An arrest warrant has been issued against 20 individuals, including former Bal Mandir officials, for allegedly embezzling charity land.

title: President attends Law Day celebration, emphasizing the importance of the rule of law and equal access to justice for all.
content:
On Law Day in Nepal, the Supreme Court celebrated with a reception attended by top officials including the President.

Chief Justice Shrestha emphasized the importance of reforming the judiciary and ensuring constitutional rights.

Law Day commemorates the establishment of the judiciary in 2008 BS, which upholds rule of law and separation of powers.

Vice President Yadav, Prime Minister Dahal, and other officials also attended the event, along with representatives from the legal community.
summary: Law Day 2081 BS was celebrated with events hosted by the Supreme Court, attended by dignitaries and legal professionals, commemorating the introduction of the Chief Court Act in 2008 BS.

title: The Federal Parliament's budget session starts today.
content: The budget meeting of Nepal's parliament starts today. The meeting was called by President Paudel, based on the government's advice. Members of parliament should attend the meeting, which starts at 2pm today at the International Conference Centre. On May 28, the government will present its budget for the next year. Before this, the President will present the government's plans and policies for the year. The meeting will be led by Speaker Devraj Ghimire, who has already met with leaders of major political parties.
summary: Nepal's federal parliament's budget session commences today, as required by constitutional provisions, with the President scheduled to present the government's policy and program and the budget on May 28th.

title: Construction of a bridge on the Narayangadh-Muglin road section is ongoing and progressing well.
content: New bridges are being built on the Narayangadh-Muglin road. Out of 15 bridges, 11 are already in use. The remaining 4 bridges will be completed by mid-November. These bridges are being built to reduce landslides and make the road safer.
summary: Construction of 15 bridges on the Narayangadh-Muglin road section is underway, with 11 operational, 2 near completion in July, and the remaining, including Tuin Khola, scheduled for November due to compensation and road access issues.

content: Janata Samajwadi Party (JSP) in Nepal will take legal action against a party split by a faction led by Ashok Rai, who got official recognition from the Election Commission. JSP's central executive committee will meet on Wednesday to discuss the split and decide on legal steps to be taken.

content:

content: The Nepal Embassy in the USA returned 24 ancient artifacts to Nepal. A woman named Susan Bradford donated the artifacts, most of which are from the 17th and 18th centuries. The Embassy is working to recover lost Nepali artifacts and has returned 63 in the past year.
summary: The Embassy of Nepal in Washington, DC repatriated 24 Nepali artifacts to the Department of Archaeology, Nepal, after receiving them from a private collector in Maui, Hawaii, as part of its ongoing efforts to recover lost Nepali cultural heritage.

The collapse happened during maintenance work, damaging a wall along the road.

title: Nepal and Korea preparing for a high-level visit.
content:
Nepal and South Korea will celebrate 50 years of diplomatic relations with high-level visits and events throughout the year.

South Korea is a major investor in Nepal, especially in the automotive and hydropower sectors. Nepal is also a key source of workers for South Korea, with over 100,000 Nepalis currently employed there.

Nepali workers are expanding their roles in South Korea beyond traditional sectors like agriculture and manufacturing, now including service and forestry.

Nepalis who return home after working in South Korea often start their own businesses, contributing to job creation in Nepal.
summary: Nepal and South Korea celebrate 50th anniversary of diplomatic relations, with high-level visits planned, increased Korean investment in Nepal, and expanded opportunities for Nepali workers in South Korea.

title: Japan and Nepal have many similarities, according to Japan's Foreign Minister Kamikawa Yoko.
content:
Japan and Nepal share many similarities:

**Geography:**
* Both countries have mountainous terrain.

**History:**
* Both countries have faced natural disasters like earthquakes.

**Democracy:**
* Both countries are democratic, and Japan has assisted Nepal's democratization efforts.

**Economic Support:**
* Japan has provided financial and technical assistance to Nepal for infrastructure, education, healthcare, and more.

**People-to-People:**
* Over 170,000 Nepalis live in Japan, strengthening the bilateral relationship.

**Women's Empowerment:**
* Japan is committed to promoting women's roles in peace and security, and Nepal is a major contributor to UN peacekeeping operations.

**Moving Forward:**
* Japan will continue to support Nepal's economic growth, stability, and development beyond its graduation from Least Developed Country status in 2026.
summary: Japan and Nepal share mountainous terrain, democratic values, and a history of earthquake disaster relief, with Japan providing support in infrastructure, education, healthcare, and promoting women's inclusion in peace and security efforts.

title: Do not seek foreign employment through illegal routes. Contact your embassy for assistance and guidance.
content:
The Embassy of Nepal in Islamabad has urged all the concerned to only use legal means to go for foreign employment, noting many Nepali have been victimized and stranded in Kyrgyzstan for some time on temptation of attractive jobs.The embassy said it has received information that some of those victimized have been assured to be sent to other countries using Kyrgyzstan route, sharing that some of the stranded people have been rescued and sent back to Nepal, some are on their way back but the process of reaching there has not stopped.
In a statement issued on Tuesday, the embassy said, "As per the information received, some Nepali and foreigners are being involved in the fraudulent acts in the face of lucrative jobs".
Individuals and groups involved in illegal activities of taking Nepali citizens abroad on the wrong temptation and leaving them stranded have to face the prevailing law, the statement further noted.
"The embassy sincerely requests all concerned not to fall prey to the ill-intended act of fraudulent groups and to use only the established and legal route arranged by the Government of Nepal to go for foreign employment", the statement reads.
summary: Nepalese Embassy in Islamabad warns against using illegal means to attain employment abroad after reports of victimization in Kyrgyzstan surface.

content: Prime Minister Prachanda says the government's upcoming budget and plans will be designed to help those who are economically disadvantaged and lay the foundation for socialism. title:
**Nepal Swadeshi Summit 2024 Declaration**

A 35-point declaration was issued at the Nepal Swadeshi Summit 2024, outlining goals for:

* Promoting domestic production
* Reducing imports
* Fostering innovation
* Creating jobs
* Strengthening the national economy
content:
The Make in Nepal Summit concluded with a declaration to promote local industry and domestic production.

The government will support domestic production, procure local products, and encourage investment.

The declaration includes:

* Reforming laws to create an industry-friendly environment
* Prioritizing domestic products for consumers
* Ensuring raw material availability
* Establishing a specialized financial institution for industrial investment
* Using local products in government gifts
* Creating a portal to identify domestic products
* Implementing One Stop Service Centre effectively
* Developing industrial areas through public-private partnerships
* Restricting imports of self-sufficient products
* Encouraging domestic production and imports
* Imposing fines instead of criminal charges for industrial violations
* Creating a separate Act to regulate the industrial sector
* Reviewing trade and investment agreements and forging a common political viewpoint for stability
summary: The Make in Nepal-Swadheshi Summit-2024 concluded with a 35-point declaration advocating for empowering local industries, increasing domestic production, and promoting consumption.

title: Over 11,000 cases of dengue have been reported in the Bagmati province.
content:
**Dengue Fever in Bagmati Province**

Over 11,000 cases of dengue fever have been reported in the Bagmati Province in the past 9 months. 

**Highest Cases:** Dhading (3,501)
**Lowest Cases:** Rasuwa (2)

**Other Districts with Cases:** 
- Kathmandu (3,000)
- Chitwan (1,708)
- Makwanpur (857)
- Bhaktapur (494)
- Kavrepalanchowk (167)

**Precautions:**
Dengue fever is caused by mosquito bites. The risk is higher in summer. People should take precautions against the disease.
summary: Over 11,000 dengue cases have been confirmed in Bagmati Province in the past nine months, with the highest number in Dhading and one fatality in Makwanpur.

title: Nepal uses a rights-based approach to population and development, ensuring everyone's rights and well-being are considered in policies and programs.
content:
- Nepal believes everyone deserves fair treatment in population and development.
- Nepal follows a strategy that respects people's rights and includes everyone.
- Implementing the plan from the 1994 conference is key to reaching the goals set for 2030.
- Nepal values the goals of the conference and has been working to achieve them.
- Even though progress has been made since the conference, not all countries have made the same amount of progress.
- Challenges like pandemics and climate change have made it harder to reach goals.
- Nepal is committed to:
    - Putting people first in development
    - Respecting human rights
    - Promoting gender equality
    - Protecting sexual and reproductive health and rights
summary: Nepal committed to a rights-based approach in population and development, emphasizing ICPD implementation, ongoing efforts to improve citizen quality of life, and addressing global challenges and inequalities.

title: Japan has donated a community center to help prevent disasters.
content: Japan donated a Community Center to Indrawati Rural Municipality in Sindhupalchowk District, Nepal to improve disaster prevention capabilities. The project included building a center, committees, activities, broadcasting, warehouses, and landslide prevention measures. The center is expected to strengthen disaster prevention and support the region's growth.
summary: Japanese government hands over Community Center for Disaster Prevention to Indrawati Rural Municipality, enhancing disaster preparedness through infrastructure and initiatives led by Japanese NGO JAFS.

title: Dr. Sharma, a parliamentarian, donated 2 million rupees to a children's hospital to support their services and provide necessary care to young patients.
content:
Dr Sunil Sharma, a member of the House of Representatives, donated two million rupees to the Children's Hospital that is being built by Dr Bhagwan Koirala.

The hospital aims to build specialized children's hospitals in all seven provinces of Nepal, with a 100-bed hospital in Kathmandu.

The hospital in Damak, Jhapa, is already operational. The plan is to build 50-bed hospitals in the other provinces once the Kathmandu hospital is complete.
summary: MP Sunil Sharma donated two million rupees to support the construction of Kathmandu Institute of Child Health, a specialized children's hospital being built by Cardiothoracic Surgeon Dr Bhagwan Koirala.

title: Dr. Sharma, a parliamentarian, donated Rs. 2 million to a children's hospital.
content: Dr. Sharma, a politician, donated 2 million rupees to a children's hospital being built by Dr. Koirala, a heart surgeon. KIOCH, led by Dr. Koirala, plans to build children's hospitals in all seven provinces of Nepal, and one in Kathmandu will have 100 beds. After the Kathmandu hospital is built, 50-bed hospitals will be built in each province.
summary: Member of Parliament Dr. Sunil Sharma donates 2 million rupees to support the construction of a specialized children's hospital in Kathmandu, while KIOCH plans to expand to all seven provinces.

title: Children are being given vitamin A capsules and deworming tablets.
content: The Department of Health Services in Nepal is giving free Vitamin 'A' capsules to children under 5 years old and de-worming tablets to children from 1 to 5 years old for two days. The goal is to give Vitamin 'A' to about 3.2 million children and de-worming tablets to about 2.9 million children. Health volunteers will give the supplements to children in every ward. The government does this twice a year.
summary: As part of the National Vitamin 'A' program, children under five in Nepal are being administered vitamin 'A' capsules and de-worming tablets by 52,000 women health volunteers and 10,000 health workers.

title: 414 climbers given permit to climb Mount Everest this spring season.
content:
As many as 414 people have taken permission for expediting Mount Everest or Sagarmatha, the world's highest peak, in the spring season this year.According to the Department of Tourism, a total of 414 climbers, including 75 women and 339 men of 41 mountaineering groups have so far been permitted for the same.
The highest number of climbers (478) had obtained permission for ascent to the Mount Everest last year.
According to Section Officer at the Department, Chun Bahadur Tamang, a total of 971 mountaineers from 112 climbing group had obtained permission for ascending to 30 mountains, including the Mount Everest this season.
A total royalty of Rs 674.7 million has been so far collected from mountaineering permission. Around Rs 592.3 million has been raised from the Mount Everest alone in the season.
summary: This spring, 414 climbers (75 women, 339 men) have received permits to ascend Mount Everest, generating Rs 674.7 million in royalty, with Rs 592.3 million coming from Everest ascents.

title: Pepper chips left on top of Mount Makalu, the world's fifth-highest mountain.
content:
Australian mountaineer Allie Pepper climbed Mount Makalu, the world's fifth-highest mountain, without extra oxygen.

She has now climbed 10 of 14 eight-thousand-meter peaks in 2 years without extra oxygen, making her the first Australian woman to do so.

Pepper plans to complete the remaining 10 peaks by 2025, with her next target being Mount Kanchenjunga, the world's third-highest.
summary: Australian mountaineer Allie Pepper scaled Mount Makalu, the world's fifth highest, without oxygen, becoming the first Australian female to summit 10 of 14 eight-thousanders without supplemental oxygen.

title: Pepper is now the second person and first woman to reach the top of the fifth highest mountain, Makalu, while on a blindfolded expedition.
content:
Australian mountaineer Allie Pepper has summited Mount Makalu, the world's fifth highest mountain, without using extra oxygen.

With this summit, Pepper has climbed 10 of the 14 eight-thousand-meter peaks within two years. She aims to be the first Australian woman to climb all 14 peaks without supplemental oxygen.

Pepper's next target is Mount Kanchenjunga, the world's third-highest peak. She plans to climb eight more mountains in Pakistan to complete her goal by 2025.

Pepper's journey highlights the strength and determination of women in mountaineering.
summary: Australian mountaineer Allie Pepper scaled Mount Makalu without supplemental oxygen, becoming the first Australian woman to summit 10 out of 14 eight-thousanders within two years.

title: PM announces a fund to support innovation and expansion of the IT sector.
content:
Prime Minister Dahal plans to create an "innovation fund" in the upcoming budget to support the information technology (IT) sector in Nepal.

The government believes that developing, expanding, and using IT can transform Nepal's economy and society.

The Prime Minister also emphasized the importance of integrating and implementing the "Startup Programme" for youth entrepreneurship.

He stressed that IT is crucial for development, good governance, and employment, and urged everyone to contribute to its rapid growth in Nepal.

The government is committed to creating policies and laws to promote safe and responsible use of IT.

Measures will be taken to control cybercrime through legal and policy actions.
summary: Prime Minister Dahal pledged to establish an innovation fund for IT sector expansion, formulate necessary laws, integrate startup programs for youth empowerment, and control cybercrime through legal measures.

title: Today is National ICT Day, a celebration of the role of Information and Communication Technology (ICT) in society.
content: Today is National ICT Day in Nepal. The day is celebrated to promote technology in the country. The government is hosting an event with awards for those who have helped the ICT sector. The government is working to use technology to improve the country's economy and society.
summary: National ICT Day is celebrated annually on May 2 to promote ICT development and recognize outstanding contributions to the sector, with Prime Minister Dahal presiding over the main ceremony and the government emphasizing ICT's role in socio-economic transformation.

title: Politics can boost investor enthusiasm and lead to positive investment outcomes for the president.
content:
**Summary:**

President Ramchandra Paudel believes that:

* Politics should encourage investors to invest in Nepal's rich natural resources and energy sector.
* Nepal can become prosperous by developing its energy sector through public-private partnerships.
* Federalism and democracy are creating a stable environment for investments.
* Nepal is now an energy exporter and is playing a positive role in the region by providing clean energy.
summary: President Paudel emphasizes the role of politics in attracting investment for Nepal's prosperity, highlighting the potential of energy development and the government's commitment to creating an enabling environment.

title:
A proposed law aims to make sure that artificial intelligence (AI) is used in a clear and responsible way. It makes sure that:

* People know how AI is being used.
* AI is not used in a way that hurts people or takes away their rights.
* There are ways to fix problems if things go wrong.
content:
**IT Management and Cybersecurity Draft Bill**

The government proposes a bill to manage IT and cybersecurity. It encourages the use of AI, machine learning, blockchain, and IoT responsibly.

**Key Provisions:**

* Establishment of a center for research and development in new technologies
* Directors' committee headed by the Minister of Communications and Information Technology
* Coordination committee for quick response to cybersecurity incidents
* Inclusion of regulations on electronic records, data safety, digital signatures, and IT audits

**Prohibited Activities:**

* Disruption of national unity, security, or territorial integrity through electronic systems
* Cyberbullying, harassment, and distribution of indecent content
* Theft of data and code

**Data Privacy:**

* Government cannot collect personal data without informing individuals
* Websites of government bodies and public corporations must meet standards set by the Ministry
* Registration and licensing of cybersecurity service providers
summary: Nepal's draft IT/cyber security bill promotes innovative technologies (AI, ML, blockchain, IoT), establishes a research center, structures governance, includes data protection, bans cyberbullying, and mandates website standards for government entities.

title: Cyber laws are needed to resolve internet-related issues.
content: Cyber laws are needed to fix problems, says Minister Sharma. The government is working on a cyber security law and wants suggestions from everyone. Cyber security is important because of the risks of misusing information technology. The government is spreading awareness about cyber security because it's a sensitive issue that needs informed citizens to handle it.
summary: Minister Sharma urges cyber legislation to address issues, highlights importance of public awareness and government collaboration on cyber security.

title: India is in positive talks with Bangladesh to export energy, including electricity and natural gas.
content: Nepal and Bangladesh agreed to start trading electricity soon. Nepal will sell electricity to Bangladesh during the upcoming rainy season. The details of the deal are being finalized and will be approved by both sides soon.
summary: Nepal and Bangladesh discuss power trade deal, aiming to export electricity from Nepal to Bangladesh during the upcoming rainy season.

title: The Japan Foundation presents "Yakishime: Earth Metamorphosis," a traveling exhibition showcasing traditional Japanese pottery techniques. This exhibition travels to various locations, bringing the beauty and artistry of Yakishime pottery to a wider audience.
content:
**Japan Culture Exhibition in Nepal**

An exhibition of "Yakishime" ceramics, a traditional Japanese art form, will be held at the Embassy of Japan in Kathmandu from May 11th to 30th.

Yakishime is a type of unglazed pottery that has been fired at high temperatures. It is often used for serving food and drink, and has a unique and rustic beauty.

The exhibition will explore the history and uses of Yakishime ceramics, and will showcase a variety of pieces from traditional tea wares to contemporary art objects.

Admission is free, and the exhibition is open to the public from 9:30am to 4:30pm daily.
summary: The Embassy of Japan and Japan Foundation will host an exhibition on the development, history, and cultural significance of unglazed, high-fired Japanese ceramics known as yakishime.

title: Chhabi Lal Lohani, a renowned and veteran actor, has passed away.
content: CP Lohani, the star of Nepal's first hit movie "Maitighar," died today at 86. He passed away in a hospital due to Alzheimer's and pneumonia. Lohani also worked in government and in the film and music industry. He was married to Bollywood actress Mala Sinha. His cremation will take place today at Pashupati Aryaghat.
summary: Renowned Nepali actor CP Lohani, known for his role in "Maitighar", passed away at age 86 due to Alzheimer's and pneumonia.

title:
Democratic Republic:

- Looks to religion for guidance on how to live
content: President Paudel believes that religions, including Nepal's Federal Democratic Republic, focus on moral values and human well-being. All religions aim to create a peaceful, just, and civilized society. He congratulated the Jain community on Lord Mahabir's birth anniversary and encouraged them to continue promoting non-violence and positive values.
summary: President Paudel addressed Nepal Jain Parishad on Lord Mahabir's birth anniversary, highlighting the shared moral values and welfare goals of religions, and urging the Parishad to promote Jain principles of non-violence, peace, and social service.

title: Chaiti Chhath festival concludes with devotees offering prayers to the rising sun.
content: Chaite Chhath festival has ended. Devotees offered water to the sun on Sunday evening and Monday morning. This festival is celebrated twice a year to wish for good things for their families.
summary: Chaiti Chhath festival in Mithila concludes with devotees offering 'argha' to the rising sun after fasting since Saturday night.

title: Socialism requires a culture that supports its principles. This culture includes values like equality, cooperation, and social responsibility. By fostering such a culture, we can create a foundation for a socialist society.
content:
**Socialist Culture is Key to Building Socialism**

Prime Minister Dahal believes that fostering a socialist culture is crucial for creating a foundation for socialism. He emphasized the need for collaboration among patriotic communities in promoting this culture. The government is committed to supporting cultural institutions through policies, funding, and infrastructure. The Sanskritik Sansthan's Cultural Evening showcased the country's diverse cultural heritage, inspiring unity and promoting cultural diversity.
summary: Prime Minister Dahal emphasized cultural transformation and socialist culture as foundations for socialism, pledging support for the Sanskritik Sansthan's cultural evening showcasing Nepali diversity.

title: The Attorney-General's decision to clear the Home Minister of wrongdoing has sparked controversy. Some people believe it is unfair, while others support the decision.
content:
After being cleared of passport issues, Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Home Affairs Rabi Lamichhane has now received a letter from the Office of the Attorney General stating that there are no cases against him in cooperative fraud cases.

This letter has drawn criticism as it's the first of its kind from the OAG. The OAG claims it's just providing information and does not clear Lamichhane or prevent new cases from being filed.

Critics argue that the OAG should not issue such letters, as it may set a wrong precedent. The Nepali Congress has previously demanded a parliamentary panel to investigate the fraud charges against Lamichhane.

Despite the letter from the OAG, the Nepali Congress claims that Lamichhane is involved in misusing funds from three cooperatives.
summary: Amid dual passport case acquittal and cooperative fraud allegations, the Attorney General's Office issued a letter indicating no cases against Deputy Prime Minister Rabi Lamichhane, sparking criticism for setting a questionable precedent.

title: Political tensions in Nepal's Madhesh region have escalated after the split of the erstwhile ruling coalition government. The fate of the coalition is uncertain, and different parties are maneuvering for power and influence.
content:
The Janata Samajbadi Party (JSP) in Nepal has split up, which could put the provincial government in Madhesh at risk.

The Maoist Centre party, which supports the Madhesh government, is considering forming a new government with other parties.

The Maoist Centre had been unhappy with the JSP's performance and wanted the finance ministry, but was not given it.

The UML, which is the largest party in the provincial assembly, is also interested in leading the government.

The fate of the Madhesh government depends on the decision of the ruling coalition in Kathmandu.

If the coalition decides to support a new government, the JSP may have to step down from power.
summary: The split in Janata Samajbadi Party-Nepal (JSP-Nepal) may lead to a crisis in the Madhesh provincial government, with the Maoist Centre considering forming a new government in the province.

title: Government plans to check expecting mothers for mental health issues.
content:
**Government to Screen Pregnant Women for Mental Health**

To reduce maternal deaths, Nepal's Health Ministry plans to screen pregnant women for mental health problems. Self-harm, like suicide, has been a leading cause of maternal deaths in Nepal.

The screening program will start in Kathmandu and expand to other districts in the future. The goal is to prevent suicides by providing timely treatment for mental health issues.

Nepal aims to reduce the maternal mortality rate to 75 per 100,000 births by 2030.
summary: Nepal's Ministry of Health plans to screen pregnant women for mental health issues to reduce maternal deaths, with 6% of deaths attributed to self-harm and alarmingly high postpartum hemorrhage and pre-eclampsia rates.

title: Businesses are asking the government to invest heavily to revive the economy.
content:
Nepal's private sector asks the government to make a bigger investment in the economy to promote economic growth in the upcoming budget. 

They want the government to make it easier for businesses to invest so that the private sector can invest more money. 

Private investment has been slow in recent years, and the government's spending has also decreased. This has led to a slowdown in the economy. Both private and public sector investments are low at the moment, so economists do not expect Nepal's economy to grow quickly in the near future. 

The private sector wants the budget to include programs that encourage investment, such as a "decade of investment" and special treatment for businesses that create many jobs. 

The government should also consider using money from the Social Security Fund, Citizens Investment Trust, and Employees Provident Fund to invest in development and infrastructure projects to create jobs. 

The banking sector is also facing challenges, and the budget needs to address this by making it easier for businesses to borrow money and by investing in financial technology. 

The government needs to address the issues of hedging and foreign direct investment to attract more foreign investment. The budget should also include measures to promote a green economy and increase productivity.
summary: Nepal's private sector seeks increased government capital expenditure in the upcoming budget to stimulate economic growth due to sluggish private investment, as the economy faces a slowdown.

title: Nepalese cuisine is now available in New York City, offering diners a taste of Nepal.
content:

* Mishra uses traditional ingredients and flavors in his cooking.
* He believes chefs should be creative and cook what they love.

content:

* Lamichhane has denied any wrongdoing, claiming he received no loans from cooperatives.
* Office of the Attorney General issued a letter stating no cases exist against Lamichhane in cooperative fraud cases, sparking criticism.

title: cruellest-crime
content: Nepal's Central Investigation Bureau has issued arrest warrants for 20 people involved in a land lease scam that illegally rented out land from the Nepal Children's Organization to a private school. The scam allowed private individuals to make money from land meant for helping children in need. This is similar to other land grab scams in Nepal, and it highlights the need for the government to crack down on such illegal activities and protect public property. The media has played a key role in exposing these issues, and they should continue to do so.
summary: Central Investigation Bureau issues arrest warrants against 20 individuals involved in Nepal Children’s Organization land lease scam, targeting former organization officials and business representatives who illegally leased land and sublet it for profit.

title:
**Unveiling PhD Sagas**

PhD journeys are often not linear. They involve unexpected turns, setbacks, and challenges. Researchers have shared their experiences through storytelling to highlight the complexities and triumphs of their academic adventures. This approach offers valuable insights and support for current and future PhD candidates.
content:
**PhD by Coursework at Tribhuvan University (TU)**

In 2016, TU switched to a "PhD by coursework" model, where students take classes instead of writing a dissertation. While this approach is common in other countries, TU's implementation has limitations.

**Benefits of PhD by Coursework:**

* Exposes students to a wide range of topics in their field.
* Prepares them to conduct original research.
* Equips them to teach a variety of courses.

**Challenges at TU:**

* The dean's office controls the programs, limiting the departments' ability to offer needed courses.
* Many departments lack qualified faculty to teach doctoral-level courses.
* The Sewa Ayog's recruitment process is slow and biased, making it difficult to hire new faculty.
* Political and personal conflicts among faculty hinder collaboration necessary for successful teamwork.

As a result, the "PhD by coursework" program at TU is not meeting the needs of students who want to develop their research skills. To improve the program, TU needs to make changes to its recruitment process and encourage faculty collaboration.
summary: Tribhuvan University (TU) implemented a "PhD by coursework" route for its Humanities and Social Sciences Faculty doctoral students, replacing the "PhD by dissertation" route, but the execution of the new modality faces challenges in course delivery and faculty competence.

title: Everest, the world's highest mountain, is burdened with tons of garbage left behind by climbers. This includes oxygen tanks, tents, food wrappers, and human waste. The harsh conditions and altitude make cleanup efforts extremely difficult and costly.
content:
**Mount Everest's Trash Problem**

* Climbing season (April-May) attracts many adventurers to Mount Everest.
* Everest's Nepal side is littered with garbage, including human waste.
* About 60,000 people visit Everest's national park each year, generating tons of waste.
* Waste can contaminate water, air, and soil.
* Initiatives are underway to address this problem:
    * Sagarmatha Pollution Control Committee monitors garbage.
    * Nepal requires climbers to bring back waste or forfeit a deposit.
    * Sagarmatha Next promotes sustainable tourism and collects garbage.
    * University of Colorado developed a waste management plan.
    * NeverRest Project proposes a sustainable base camp with technologies to reduce waste.

These efforts aim to improve the environment for climbers and local communities around Mount Everest.
summary: Every spring, hundreds of climbers flock to Nepal and Tibet to summit Mount Everest, facing severe trash accumulation, with ongoing efforts to address the issue using technology and international collaboration.

content:

title: Israel attacked eastern Rafah, Gaza after ceasefire talks ended without an agreement.
content:
**Israeli Bombardment of Rafah**

Israel continued to attack Rafah, the largest city in Gaza. Despite US warnings, Israel is determined to proceed with its operation in Rafah and other areas.

Palestinian militants fired rockets at Israeli tanks, while Israeli airstrikes killed at least 21 people, including civilians.

**Indirect Peace Talks**

Indirect peace talks in Cairo ended with no agreement between Hamas and Israel. Hamas rejected Israeli objections to its hostage release proposal.

**Humanitarian Crisis**

The closure of the Rafah crossing with Egypt has cut off aid, food, and medical supplies. The only kidney dialysis center in the area has stopped operating due to shelling. The medical sector has collapsed.

**US Threat and Israeli Response**

US President Biden threatened to withhold weapons if Israel launched a ground invasion of Rafah. Israel responded that it would continue with its operation regardless.
summary: Israeli forces bombarded areas of Rafah on Thursday, Palestinian residents said, as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu dismissed US President Joe Biden’s threat to withhold weapons from Israel if it assaults the southern Gaza city.A senior Israeli official said late on Thursday that the latest round of indirect negotiations in Cairo to halt hostilities in Gaza had ended and Israel would proceed with its operation in Rafah and other parts of the Gaza Strip as planned.Israel has submitted to mediators its reservations about a Hamas proposal for a hostage release deal, the official said.“If we must, we shall fight with our fingernails,” Netanyahu said in a video statement. “But we have much more than our fingernails.”In Gaza, Palestinian militant groups Hamas and Islamic Jihad said their fighters fired anti-tank rockets and mortars at Israeli tanks massed on the eastern outskirts of the city.Residents and medics in Rafah, the biggest urban area in Gaza not yet overrun by Israeli ground forces, said an Israeli attack near a mosque killed at least three people and wounded others in the eastern Brazil neighbourhood.Video footage from the scene showed the minaret lying in the rubble and two bodies wrapped in blankets.An Israeli air strike on two houses in the Sabra neighbourhood of Rafah killed at least 12 people including women and children.Among the dead was a senior commander of the militant Al-Mujahedeen Brigades, and his family, and the family of another group leader, medics, relatives and the group said.Israel says Hamas militants are hiding in Rafah, where the population has been swelled by hundreds of thousands of Gazans seeking refuge from the bombardments that have reduced most of the coastal enclave to ruins.In the United States, the White House repeated its hope that Israel would not launch a full operation in Rafah, saying it did not believe that would advance Israel’s aim of defeating Hamas.“Smashing into Rafah, in [President Biden’s] view, will not advance that objective,” spokesperson John Kirby said.Kirby said Hamas had been pressured significantly by Israel and there were better options to hunt down what remains of the group’s leadership than an operation with significant risk to civilians.Israel’s assault on Gaza has killed nearly 35,000 Palestinians and wounded nearly 80,000, most of them civilians, the health ministry in Hamas-run Gaza said.It launched its offensive in response to a cross-border attack by Hamas militants on Israel on October 7 in which they killed about 1,200 people and abducted 252. Some 128 hostages remain in Gaza and 36 have been declared dead, according to the latest Israeli figures.Biden on Wednesday issued his starkest warning yet against a full ground invasion in Rafah, telling CNN that: “I made it clear that if they go into Rafah...I’m not supplying the weapons.”Israel’s ambassador to the United States said the decision to withhold weapons from Israel over Rafah sends the “wrong message” to Hamas and the country’s foes.“It puts us in a corner because we have to deal with Rafah one way or the other,” Ambassador Michael Herzog told a Carnegie Endowment for International Peace webinar.The Israeli military has the munitions it requires for operations in Rafah and other planned operations, chief armed forces spokesperson Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari said.Israeli armed forces have already killed 50 Palestinian gunmen in east Rafah and uncovered several tunnels, Hagari said. Hamas had no immediate comment.TALKS ENDIn Cairo, delegations from Hamas, Israel, the US, Egypt and Qatar had been meeting since Tuesday. The talks in Egypt’s capital made some headway but no deal was reached, according to two Egyptian security sources.Izzat El-Risheq, a member of Hamas’ political office in Qatar, said the Hamas delegation had left Cairo, having reaffirmed its approval of the mediators’ ceasefire proposal. The plan entails the release of Israeli hostages held captive in Gaza and a number of Palestinians jailed by Israel.Hamas blames Israel for the lack of agreement, and its Al-Aqsa TV’s Telegram account said the group would not make any concessions beyond those in the proposal it had accepted.Israel has said it is open to a truce, but has rejected demands for an end to the war.US State Department spokesperson Matthew Miller said Washington continued to engage with Israel on amendments to a ceasefire proposal, adding work to finalise the text of an agreement was “incredibly difficult”.MEDICAL SECTOR COLLAPSINGIsraeli residents set fire twice to the perimeter of the headquarters of the UN agency for Palestinian refugees in East Jerusalem, causing extensive damage to the outdoor areas but no casualties, UNRWA chief Philippe Lazzarini wrote on X. There was no immediate comment from Israeli police.“Once again, the lives of UN staff were at a serious risk,” Lazzarini wrote, adding he had decided to close the compound until security is restored.On Tuesday, Israeli tanks seized the Gaza side of the Rafah border crossing with Egypt, cutting off a vital aid route and forcing 80,000 people to flee the city this week, according to the United Nations.Israel kept up tank and aerial strikes across Gaza and tanks advanced in the Zeitoun neighbourhood of Gaza City in the north, forcing hundreds of families to flee, residents said. The Israeli military said it was securing Zeitoun, starting with a series of intelligence-based aerial strikes on approximately 25 militant targets.Deir Al-Balah in central Gaza was packed with people who had fled Rafah in recent days. Palestinian medics said two people, including a woman, were killed when a drone fired a missile at a group of people there.The closure of the Rafah crossing with Egypt has prevented the evacuation of the wounded and sick and the entry of medical supplies, food trucks and fuel needed to operate hospitals, the Gaza health ministry said on Thursday.The only kidney dialysis centre in the Rafah area had stopped operating due to the shelling.“The entire medical sector has collapsed,” said Ali Abu Khurma, a Jordanian surgeon volunteering at Al Aqsa hospital in Deir al-Balah.United Nations aid chief Martin Griffiths said that for three consecutive days, “nothing and no one has been allowed in or out of Gaza.”“It means no aid. title: Nepal is using drones to remove garbage from Mount Everest. These drones can carry up to 30 pounds of trash at a time, making it easier to clean up the mountain.
content:
**Drones to Clean Mount Everest**

Drones will be tested on Mount Everest to remove garbage. If successful, drones could reduce the risk for guides who climb through the dangerous Khumbu Icefall with heavy loads.

**Safety Measures for Everest Climbers**

New rules are in place to improve safety and manage garbage:
- GPS tracking devices are required.
- Climbers must camp in designated areas and use biodegradable "poop bags" to prevent waste.
- The bodies of deceased climbers are now the responsibility of their guides and agencies.
- Bright lights and commercial activities are banned at the base camp.

**Climbing Statistics**

- Around 400 climbing permits have been issued for Everest this year.
- Americans have the most permits, followed by Chinese and British climbers.
- 8,270 summit ascents have been made from the Nepal side since 1953.
summary: For the first time, high-altitude guides will face some competition on Everest… from drones.The Khumbu Pasang Lhamu Rural Municipality, which hosts the 8,848.86 metre-tall Everest, is piloting heavy lifter drones that will bring back garbage from the mighty mountain. Though officials say that cargo drones will fly on Everest to bring garbage, its success, however, may affect the livelihood of high altitude support staff who navigate the dangerous Khumbu Icefall with tonnes of loads on their backs. “It’s a test. The success means we will use drones in a full-fledged manner to bring garbage from up to 6,500 metres of Camp II, next season,” said Jagat Prasad Bhusal, chief administrative officer of the rural municipality. “We, however, have not discussed whether drones can be used to transport supplies and logistics to Camp II to reduce casualties on the notorious Khumbu Icefall.”On April 18, 2014, an avalanche resulting from a falling serac buried 16 Sherpa guides in the Khumbu Icefall that eventually led to the cancellation of the season’s expeditions. Last year, three Sherpa guides were buried under the ice masses triggered by an avalanche in the Khumbu Icefall. Their bodies have not been recovered. The Himalayan Database and the government record show that nearly 50 individuals died on the icefall from 1953 to 2023.All climbers and guides need to navigate the icefall, on the route that leads to the world’s tallest peak, which is so notoriously dangerous that even experienced Sherpas hesitate to move when the sun shines.The Khumbu Icefall, a river of ice—a kilometre or so—is normally crossed during the night or early morning with climbers putting headlamps on their helmets.Normally, the route is crossed early in the morning, the time when the ice blocks and the hanging glaciers are stable and avalanche risks are low.During the day, as the sun warms the mountain, the hanging glaciers begin to melt and ice starts to crumble, causing avalanche risk.“The Khumbu Icefall has killed many, mostly high-altitude support staff. The drone could prevent growing casualties of mountain guides at least in the stretch of the icefall,” said Bhusal. From Camp II (6,400m) to the summit, there are less chances for avalanches.The rural municipality, currently, is piloting the Chinese drone from DJI, which stands for Da-Jiang Innovations technology company headquartered in Shenzhen, Guangdong.“However, after a successful test, we could buy drones through a competitive bidding process,” said Bhusal.The drone can fly up to 6,500 metres and carry 30 kg, he said. This year, Everest is likely to be busy as always, though the number of climbers is expected to drop slightly as compared to last year’s figure. Rakesh Gurung, director at the Department of Tourism, said they have issued 390 climbing permits as of Monday. “We expect the number to be slightly over 400 this year,” he said. Last year, the department issued a record 479 Everest climbing permits. This year, the highest number of permits have been issued for Americans (70), followed by Chinese (65), British (34) and Indians (22). The number of Everest aspirants from India has dropped significantly this year, according to department officials.The department said that guides have fixed the ropes and ladders up to Camp IV at nearly 8,000 metres on Sunday and the Everest push may formally begin next week.This year, there are a slew of rules implemented to make climbing safe and manage garbage.The Department of Tourism, under the federal government rule, has made it mandatory for climbers to be strapped with a tracking chip or a GPS device.The local government of Khumbu Pasang Lhamu Rural Municipality, on March 4, introduced its own rules by implementing the Base Camp Management Procedure 2024 for the first time.Under its rules, people at the base camp have been allowed a maximum area of 80 square feet per person to sleep during a mountaineering expedition.Similarly, a maximum area of 60 square feet per person has been allocated for dining purposes at the base camp.Attached toilets shall not be placed in the sleeping tents, according to the rule. A maximum of four toilet tents, two shower tents and two urine toilet tents are allowed in each camp for the common use of up to 15 people.When fixing new ropes for mountaineering, the old ropes must be taken off and brought back to the base camp.The rural municipality has made it mandatory for the climbers to use poop bags or biodegradable bags above the base camp for proper management and disposal of night soil.“So far, five expedition teams have brought poop bags. If the team does not bring the bags, it is available in the rural municipality,” said Bhusal.The municipality-arranged bags cost Rs580 a piece. A person will not require the bags in base camp, but they have to take the bags in all camps above the base camp. “The rule is simple, no one is allowed to urinate and defecate in the open. We are forced to impose this rule to stop making Everest a minefield of poop,” said Bhusal.While climbers may not encounter the sight or smell of thawing stool, people downstream who rely on melted snow for drinking water will be more likely to take sips contaminated with dangerous bacteria and parasites.“The bags have powder or chemicals that will solidify the poops. It has a zip too,” said Bhusal. “We currently have 6,000 bags and that will be enough for this season, which lasts until May-end.” According to Bhusal, each bag will have a code. “The climbers should bring back the bags, otherwise, they will not be issued a garbage clearance certificate. Without the certificate, climbers will not be able to claim their garbage deposit money. And they will also not get the prestigious certificate of climbing Everest,” said Bhusal. Anyone visiting Everest has to pay $4,000 as a garbage deposit, and the money is refunded if the person returns with 8 kg of garbage and the bags they have used while climbing.According to the local government’s rules, in case of the death of a mountaineer, the guides, the trekking and travel agencies concerned shall be responsible for managing the body. Industry insiders say there has been an increasing trend of leaving the bodies on the mountain though they are covered by insurance.A mountaineering official said that retrieving a body in the Death Zone is a costly affair. The zone is the part of Everest that lies above 8,000 metres.Removing bodies from higher camps is expensive and difficult because of the danger of the rarefied (low oxygen) atmosphere. According to mountaineering officials, it may cost $20,000 to $200,000 to bring down a dead body from extreme points.Most climbers’ bodies are left behind on Everest every year due to the difficulties and cost factors.According to Gurung, 17 people climbing from the Nepal side died on Everest last spring season and six bodies have yet to be recovered.Taking into account the cultural sensitivity of the Sagarmatha National Park, which is listed on the UNESCO Natural Heritage Sites list, the picturesque natural scenery and the magnificent Sherpa culture, commercial operation of bars, bakeries, cafes and spas are not allowed at the base camp.Likewise, bright and flickering lights visible from a distance should not be lit in the base camp. Except in an emergency, the lights in the base camp premises must be compulsorily turned off at night.According to the department, there have been 8,270 summit ascents from the Nepal side since 1953.

title: Lack of clear adoption rules in Nepal makes it difficult to adopt children.
content: Anistha Shrestha's desire for a family was almost given up after losing a newborn and experiencing a miscarriage. However, in 2017, she and her husband found an abandoned baby and raised him as their own. While Nepal has made legal domestic adoption possible, the process is still cumbersome. Prospective parents must file an application and meet certain criteria (e.g., being married for 10 years). The well-being of children is prioritized, and adoption is only considered if no other relations can be found. However, the system lacks guidelines and regulations, making it difficult to match children with suitable parents. As a result, potential parents often find children through illegal means to keep the origins of their adopted children hidden. The heteronormative nature of Nepali society and the law also prevents queer communities from adopting children. Inter-country adoptions have been banned since 2019 due to concerns about child trafficking and abuse. Regulation is necessary to ensure child safety and prevent mishandling.
summary: After a decade of failed attempts, Anistha Shrestha and her husband found hope in finding an abandoned baby, despite ongoing challenges in Nepal's adoption system, including legal barriers for queer couples and the need for stronger regulations to ensure child safety and well-being.

title: Escalating Middle East conflict threatens Nepal's economy, as it relies on the region for remittances, tourism, and trade.
content:
Nepal's economy relies heavily on money sent home by its citizens who work in other countries, especially in the Middle East. If tensions in the Middle East escalate, such as the recent attack by Iran on Israel, it could hurt the labor market and reduce the money being sent home. This could have severe consequences for Nepal's economy, including:

- Increased unemployment and social unrest
- Reduced foreign currency reserves
- Higher inflation due to rising oil prices
- Disrupted supply chains and increased shipping costs
- Reduced tourism and foreign aid
- A stronger dollar, which can also hurt the economy

The government of Nepal and other organizations are already preparing for the potential economic impact of the conflict in the Middle East.
summary: Escalating tensions in the Middle East threaten Nepal's remittance-dependent economy due to potential labor market shocks and disruptions in global supply chains, leading to concerns over inflation, foreign currency reserves, and geopolitical shocks.

title: Politicians change their beliefs when it's easier for them.
content:
Last year, Nepali Congress rejected a demand for a judicial commission to investigate political leaders in gold smuggling.

Now, the Nepali Congress is demanding a parliamentary committee to investigate Deputy Prime Minister Lamichhane in a cooperative embezzlement case. However, the UML, the current ruling party, has rejected this demand.

The UML argues that their demand for a judicial commission in the gold smuggling case was different from the Congress's demand for a parliamentary committee in the cooperative scam.

The Congress claims that the state apparatus is trying to prove Lamichhane innocent despite evidence against him.

The differing positions of the Congress and UML on these investigations are based on their current position in government or opposition.

Experts argue that political parties should have faith in the state apparatus rather than demanding committees for rare cases.
summary: A year ago, the UML opposition party demanded a judicial commission to investigate gold smuggling allegations, which the then-coalition Nepali Congress rejected, while now the UML, part of the current coalition, opposes the Congress' demand for a parliamentary committee to probe embezzlement allegations against Home Minister Lamichhane, despite their previous support for such committees when in opposition.

summary: Nepali Congress demands a parliamentary investigation into Home Minister Lamichhane's alleged involvement in cooperative funds embezzlement, despite resistance from ruling parties.

title: Pollution in the air can cause young children to get asthma.
content:
**Air Pollution's Impact on Children**

Air pollution is making children, especially those in polluted areas like Kathmandu and Saptari, sick with asthma. This is because the air is filled with harmful substances from forest fires, cars, factories, and burning plant waste.

Children can get asthma even if they don't have a fever, but they may wheeze when they breathe out. If a child has trouble breathing, trouble sleeping, or wheezing, it's important to see a doctor.

Air pollution is also linked to other health problems like pneumonia, skin allergies, and even cancer. It can even shorten people's lives by up to 7 years in some areas of Nepal.

To protect children from air pollution, it's important to reduce the amount of pollution in the air and to seek medical help when needed.
summary: Air pollution in Nepal, particularly in Kathmandu and Saptari, has led to a rise in childhood asthma, with infants rushed to hospitals for oxygen therapy, impacting public health and shortening life expectancy by approximately five years.

title: People in 7 districts will receive medicine to prevent elephantiasis.
content:
**Mass Drug Campaign for Elephantiasis**

Preparations are ready to launch a two-week campaign on Sunday against elephantiasis in seven districts.

* **Who:** Healthy people over two years old
* **When:** Sunday for two weeks
* **Where:** Jhapa, Dhanusha, Mahottari, Sarlahi, Rautahat, Kapilvastu, and Rasuwa
* **Treatment:** Diethylcarbamazine, albendazole, and Ivermectin (new addition)

The campaign aims to prevent elephantiasis, a mosquito-borne disease that causes swelling and disability.

* **Household Visits:** Health workers will visit homes to ensure everyone receives medicine.
* **Progress:** Elephantiasis has been eliminated from 70 out of 77 districts in Nepal.

This campaign may be the last year of the program due to budget constraints.
summary: Nepal is holding a two-week mass drug administration campaign to combat lymphatic filariasis (elephantiasis) in seven endemic districts, targeting healthy individuals over two years of age in a bid to eliminate the disease.

title: Architecture and art come together to create unique and beautiful spaces.
content:
**Lucknow: A City of Smiles and Architecture**

The gate to Lucknow welcomes visitors with the message "Smile, you are in Lucknow." The city lives up to this promise with its friendly people, bustling streets, and delicious food.

**Bara Imambara: A Grand Complex**

Bara Imambara, built in 1784, is a magnificent building with a huge hall for gatherings. It was constructed as a famine relief project and designed without pillars or beams, making it a marvel of engineering.

**Asafi Mosque: A Graceful Work of Art**

Inside the complex is the beautiful Asafi Mosque, adorned with intricate calligraphy and elegant domes. It stands in serene contrast to the busy city outside.

**Asafi Hall: A Vast and Impressive Space**

The main hall, Asafi Hall, is vast and awe-inspiring. Its massive arched roof seems to float without support. The tomb of Asaf-ud-Daula lies in a vaulted chamber within the hall.

**Bhool Bhulaiyaa: A Confusing Labyrinth**

Above the hall is a confusing maze called Bhool Bhulaiyaa, or "Maze of Confusion." Every sound echoes through its corridors, creating an eerie atmosphere.

**Rooftop Views and Shahi Baoli**

From the roof, visitors can enjoy stunning views of Lucknow. Underground, the Shahi Baoli, or royal stepwell, provides a cool refuge with intricate carvings and a clever security feature that allowed its occupants to observe visitors through the water's reflection.

**A Memorable Experience**

Bara Imambara is a testament to the ingenuity and artistry of the past. It offers a fascinating and unforgettable architectural experience.
summary: The Bara Imambara, a majestic 18th-century complex in Lucknow, India, boasts the Asaf-ud-Daula's tomb, a labyrinthine Bhool Bhulaiyaa, and the underground Shahi Baoli with its CCTV-like well design.

title: Millions of migrant workers in China are unable to retire due to financial constraints, despite the country's rapidly aging population.
content:
67-year-old Hu Dexi, a former bun seller from Xian, moved to Beijing with his wife to become cleaners for 4,000 yuan ($552) each per month. Many rural migrants like Hu are reaching retirement age and face a drop in living standards as China's social security system is not enough to support them.

China's basic rural pension of 123 yuan ($17) per month is below the poverty level. Despite a 20 yuan increase in the minimum pension, it is still insufficient.

The government is prioritizing economic growth over social welfare, leading to a lack of support for the elderly. This is partly due to fears of the "middle-income trap" and a desire to catch up in industrial modernization.

China's pension system is based on a hukou system that divides people based on urban or rural residency. Rural pensions are significantly lower than urban pensions.

Raising the retirement age is a potential solution but has been delayed due to concerns about public perception.

Many elderly rural migrants are working low-paid jobs despite health issues because they cannot afford to retire. The government is facing challenges in providing adequate healthcare and social services for this growing population.
summary: Aging Chinese rural migrants face a retirement crisis, working low-paid jobs or returning to impoverished villages due to insufficient pensions and social services, as China prioritizes economic growth over social security reforms.

title: Youth from India's Maoist-affected region struggle with issues like unemployment and lack of opportunities in their hometowns. Many of them migrate to the United States in search of better prospects, but often face challenges in adapting to a new culture and finding stable jobs. Despite the difficulties, they remain hopeful and determined to build a better future for themselves and their families.
content:
**Youth from Tak Village, Nepal, Trying to Illegally Reach the US**

Many young people from Tak village in Nepal have tried to reach the United States illegally, spending large amounts of money in the process.

**Deportation and Losses:**

* Eight youth have been deported from the US, losing around $45 million in total.
* Many more have returned without completing the journey, losing unknown amounts.

**Loans and Debt:**

* Youth took loans with high interest rates to fund their trips.
* Many households have at least one person who has gone abroad, leaving behind debts and financial hardship.

**Mental Health and Social Impacts:**

* Deported youth face mental health issues, anxiety, and depression.
* Some families have left the village due to debt and societal pressure.

**Political and Economic Factors:**

* Lack of political will and legal remedies to address the issue.
* Ban on marijuana farming and economic stagnation after the Maoist insurgency have led to poverty.
* Organized human traffickers exploit this situation by offering illegal travel routes.

**Legal Challenges:**

* Police face difficulty collecting data due to lack of complaints.
* Existing laws are inadequate to fully address human trafficking cases.

**Consequences:**

* The phenomenon of illegal travel to the US is emptying villages.
* Families face financial ruin and psychological trauma.
* Organized crime and human trafficking flourish.
summary: Bharat Budha, chair of Putha Uttarganga Rural Municipality’s ward 10, knows that many youths from his village have made it to the United States via ‘tallo bato’—backdoor route—and that many are still on the way. He also knows that eight of them have been deported from the country and that they have lost a cumulative Rs45 million in the process. The deported youths say that they returned home empty-handed after facing unspeakable ordeals and lost Rs6 million each on average.The Tak village in Rukum East—a close-knit settlement of 425 houses—was considered the Maoists’ ‘base area’ during the insurgency. Village youths who reached the US through illegal routes and got deported have lost an estimated Rs40 million. The number of those who returned without completing the journey and the amount they lost remain unknown.To get to the US, the youths have taken loans at up to 36 percent interest per annum from their relatives and village landowners. In Tak village, at least one person each from half of the households has gone abroad, Budha said. “Youths started going to America about six-seven years ago,” he said. “If they could gather enough money, the whole village would try to go to the US.” Budha’s own son had reached the US illegally in 2017, spending Rs3.2 million.During the insurgency, outsize slogans of revolution would adorn the walls of houses in the village. Hoping for a better life, people from all walks of life helped out the Maoists. But now, village youths are paying the agents to illegally get to the US—a country that the Maoists used to call their ‘enemy’, an ‘imperialistic force’. This has cost the Tak village much and in multiple ways.Death of a dreamSome of the deported youths have chosen to flee the village altogether, burdened with debt and creditors’ pressure. At least five such families have already left, said a resident. The family of Ram Budha was one of them. On April 28, 2015, Ram, who had returned to Nepal after working in Malaysia for eight years, took the illegal route to the US. He travelled through arduous trails for months and finally arrived in the country. Upon reaching the country, he was detained and had to stay at the detention camp for 27 months. When his refugee application was rejected, he was deported to Nepal in mid-December 2019. He lost Rs4.5 million in the process. He now owes over Rs6 million to creditors. “After the creditors began to put pressure on me, I couldn’t live in the village peacefully,” said Ram, who currently runs a vegetable farm in Tarakeshwar, Kathmandu.While those who got to the US through illegal routes and fortunately got refugee status there narrate their stories with pride, those who have been deported or returned from half-way have tragic tales to tell.Nanda Kala Gharti, who lives in a small stone house on the upper flank of Tak village, spends her days in melancholy. Her husband, Dhanlal, had chosen to take the illegal route to the US, and Nanda Kala, a mother of four, is living with the repercussions of his decision. Dhanlal had got into the US after a six-month long arduous journey and was detained immediately. He had to spend four years in the detention camp, before he was deported to Nepal. He had already lost Rs6 million.Nanda Kala said they now have an insurmountable crisis in their hands. Pointing to her son, she exclaimed, “When will he grow up, go abroad and pay back the loans!”Dhanlal himself tried to go to Croatia once and spent 15 days in Kathmandu for the process. But after he was turned down, he returned home dejected. “Now we will submit the passport to another agent [for Dhanlal’s trip abroad],” Nanda Kala said. “There’s no point staying here.”Stories that echo each otherThe situation in Sisne Rural Municipality is similar to that of Putha Uttarganga. Here, one can hear plenty of stories of those who have tried to go to the US and those who are fighting refugee cases there. Krishna Regmi, chair of the rural municipality, personally knows seven people who have been deported from the US.Gangaram Khadka, a resident of Sisne-3, runs a bee and chicken farm. Like other young men in his village, Khadka had headed off to the US via an illegal route on 27 March, 2018. He had reached the US via the New Delhi-Moscow-Barcelona-Bogota-Panama-Costa Rica-Nicaragua-Honduras-Guatemala-Mexico route. When he finally arrived in the US, he was detained and had to spend 11 months in detention. He was deported on 15 March, 2019. He had handed over Rs3.2 millions to the agent and spent Rs2 million to fight the case to become a refugee. “It’s not possible for me to pay back the loan while working in Nepal,” he said. “I aim to pay back some interest and head off abroad again.”For six months after Khadka was deported, he had anxiety and headache, he said, adding the three people from his village who were deported like him are also struggling with their mental health.Tikaram Pun, a 40-year-old resident of Bohora village in Musikot-4, is also haunted by his past journey. In September 2017, he reached the US after crossing 17 countries with the help of organised human traffickers. Of the 41 people in his group, 31 were from Rukum East and Rukum West, he said. Pun, who was detained on arrival in the US, spent 24 months in a detention camp. His refugee application was also refused and so he was deported along with eight other Nepalis. “When I returned, I started having mental health problems. I still suffer from them,” he said. Pun is under pressure from creditors and relatives to pay back the Rs9.2 million loan he had taken for the task.Those who died on the wayA group of 10 Bangladeshis and seven Nepalis, including Rupak Bohora of Bafikot-3 in Rukum West, were on a mission to reach Costa Rica through Colombia, Caribbean Coast, Capuragana and Panama. But while they were crossing a sea, their boat capsized. As many as 12 died in the incident, including six Nepalis. Rupak’s wife, Geeta, learned about the incident only after six days, on 25 June, 2021.“I still don’t know what exactly happened,” said Geeta, who had been married off at age 19 and is now a mother of two daughters. The only thing she knows is that Rupak has died and she is now all alone. And that she has Rs5 million in loan taken for Rupak’s trip. She showed a picture of her husband on her phone to this scribe and said, “I only have memories.”Lack of political will and legal remediesThe concrete bridge over Chewang river is on the edge of Tak village. On the walls of the bridge are paintings of political theorists like Marx, Engels, Lenin, Stalin and Mao, and the iconic slogan, ‘Workers of the world, unite!’, below them. But the slogan appears to be at odds with life in the village. Given the phenomenon of illegal travels to the US through the help of organised human traffickers, the whole village appears to be emptying. Neither the local governments are concerned about the phenomenon nor are the political parties paying attention.Puniraj Gharti, chair of Putha Uttarganga Rural Municipality, said though the trend is worrying, there’s nothing he can do. “How could we stop them from making the trip when they are struggling to make a living in the village?” he said.Krishna Regmi, chair of Sisne Rural Municipality, said that the vicious cycle of poverty started after marijuana farming was banned in the country. Then the Maoist insurgency added to the woe, forcing youths to migrate. The signing of the peace agreement in 2006 didn’t herald any change in the economy either and youths are struggling to get jobs. Organised human traffickers are cashing in on this sorry state of affairs, Regmi said. “Meter byajis [usurious lenders] are also promoting this phenomenon,” he added.The phenomenon is equally rife in Dang’s Tulsipur and Ghorahi. Ramesh Kumar Pandey, chair of Ghorai-15, says that even though many heading to the US are swindled, no complaints are filed at the ward office. “Only those who attempt to go to Saudi Arabia or Qatar file the complaints,” he said.One can infer from Pandey’s statements that the families of such illegal travellers don’t want to publicise the ordeals of their family members. On the one hand, agents threaten them to not publicise the issue; on the other, they fear they themselves would be punished by law.According to the Anti-Human Trafficking Bureau, as many as 178 Nepalis, including 174 men, have been deported from the US in the five fiscal years after 2018-19. Of them, the highest 49 are from Rukum while 37 are from Dang. The data doesn’t include those who returned after making it to the half-way or those who have been fighting the legal battle in the US for refugee status. But this data is enough to show that many such youths are from the ‘base areas’ of the Maoist insurgency.SSP Jeevan Shrestha, chief of the bureau, said that data on the number of such victims and the amounts they have spent is hard to collect since complaints are rarely filed with the police. “This is human trafficking but for a lack of law, we are still compelled to launch the cases as per Human Trafficking and Transportation (Control) Act 2074 BS,” Shrestha said. “The Act provides a maximum penalty of Rs250,000 for the offenders and 50 percent of that as compensation to the victims.” Without specific law, police also invoke the theft and organised crime act to punish the offenders, he added.On the one hand, police receive no complaints; on the other, the phenomenon sees no control.Bhaskar Gautam, a political scientist, says the rise in cases of human trafficking in the insurgency’s ‘base areas’ is due to the political system’s abject failure.While the Maoists raised issues related to livelihood, nationalism and a new kind of democracy to fuel their war machine, after the peace process, it is livelihoods that have been hit the hardest, Gautam said. “The traditional way of life and economy took a hit during the insurgency,” he said. “Developments after the peace process also failed to address that. What sprang up was organised human trafficking.”(Mahesh KC in Rukum East and Durgalal KC in Dang contributed to this report.)This report is prepared in collaboration with the Center for Investigative Journalism-Nepal.
